a b s t r a c t
With increasing production from nanotechnology industries, nanomaterials are inevitably released into the aquatic environment, thereby posing a potential risk to aquatic organisms. Thus, concerns have been raised on the potential ecotoxicological effect of nanoparticle. Furthermore, the ecotoxicological consequences caused by the interaction of nanoparticles with other environmental stresses, such as seawater acidification on marine animals, have not been evaluated. In particular, whether acidification enhances the susceptibility to nanoparticles in bivalves needs to be evaluated. In the present study, we investigated the combined effects of low pH and nanoscale titanium dioxide (nano-TiO2) on some immune parameters of hemocytes in the mussel Mytilus coruscus by flow cytometry under six combinations of two pH values (7.3 and 8.1) and three nano-TiO2 concentrations (0, 2.5, and 10 mg L−1) for 14 d. Afterward, the mussels were shifted to normal conditions without nano-TiO2 at pH 8.1 for 7 d further to test their recovery from the multiple stresses. Total hemocyte count (THC), phagocytosis (Pha), esterase (Est), and lysosomal content (Lyso) decreased under low pH and high nano-TiO2 concentration conditions, whereas hemocyte mortality (HM) and reactive oxygen species (ROS) increased with nano-TiO2 concentrations under low pH conditions. The interactive effects between pH and nano-TiO2 were observed at the latter part of the exposure experiment (7 and 14 d) in most hemocyte parameters. Nano-TiO2 influenced the immune functions of mussel more severely than low pH. Slight recovery from the combined stresses was observed for HM, THC, Pha, and Lyso, but significant carry-over effects of nano-TiO2 and low pH were still observed. This study demonstrated that both low pH and high concentration of nano-TiO2 had negative effects on mussels, and these effects still acted for some time even though the mussels were already out of such stressors.

. Introduction
Ocean acidification is one of the frequent environmental stressrs that marine environments are currently facing mainly because f high anthropogenic emissions of carbon dioxide due to the comustion of fossil fuels. For marine ecosystems, recent anthropogenic limate change has caused negative impacts, which may intensify nd should be given further attention (Harley et al., 2006; Hawkins t al., 2008; Wernberg et al., 2011). Experts have predicted a drop

in seawater pH by 0.3 to 0.4 units by the end of the century and concluded that average oceanic pH will decrease altogether by 0.8 units by 2300 (Caldeira and Wickett, 2003; Feely et al., 2009; IPCC, 2013). If such acidification trend continues to intensify, a wide range of marine invertebrate species (Fabry et al., 2008; Kroeker et al., 2013; Orr et al., 2005), including 63% of echinoderms and 51.6% of mollusks, will have difficulty maintaining healthy and normal physiological activities (Lewis et al., 2016). For example, the exposure to acidified seawater strongly affects immune parameters in Chamelea gallina and Mytilus galloprovincialis (Matozzo et al., 2013). Hence, the physiological adaptations of marine organisms to ocean acidification should be studied to predict their ecological consequence (Fitzer et al., 2014).
Recently, a wide variety of studies have focused on the physiological effects of ocean acidification on many marine biota.

owever, little information is available on the interactive effects of cean acidification associated with other environmental stressors, uch as manufactured nanoparticles (NPs). With the development nd wide application of NPs, their substantial advantages have been ecognized (Bour et al., 2015). NPs have been widely applied in arious areas, including the production of more than 1800 conumer products (Bour et al., 2015; Nel et al., 2006) and hence they nevitably enter the aquatic environment (Hall et al., 2009; Menard t al., 2011). In recent years, the toxicity and safety of NPs have ecome closely reviewed issues in the field of ecotoxicology, but oxic mechanisms of various NPs have not been understood comrehensively to date (Canesi and Corsi, 2016).
An increasing number of toxicological researches have reported he toxic effects of NPs on marine invertebrates (Jiang et al., 2008; anesi and Corsi, 2016). For example, Canesi et al. (2010) found hat nanoscale titanium dioxide (nano-TiO2) induced toxic effects n the mussel M. galloprovincialis at 1–10 mg L−1 concentration. ompared with other kinds of NPs, metal-bearing NPs, especially ano-TiO2, are produced at the highest amounts (Katsumiti et al., 016). The extensive applications of nano-TiO2 will lead to an ncreased environmental concentration of titanium (Hall et al., 009) that poses a potential risk to aquatic organisms (Kaegi et al., 008). The ecotoxicity of nano-TiO2 has been considered a topic f interest and is studied in various aquatic organisms, including lgae, fish, and invertebrates (Cattaneo et al., 2009; Menard et al., 011; Canesi and Corsi, 2016). To date, a multitude of toxicologial studies on nano-TiO2 have been reported in freshwater species Kumar et al., 2012), whereas less information is available regarding
arine species, such as bivalves (Menard et al., 2011). Although a ew studies have detected sublethal effects of nano-TiO2 on bivalve emocytes (Canesi et al., 2010; Couleau et al., 2012; Wang et al., 014), such as oxidative stress and cellular damage (Barnard, 2010; urr et al., 2005), the combined effects of nano-TiO2 and seawater cidification have not been considered. In particular, the coupled ffects of NP and pH have not been identified, although they may be istinct from those single stressors with the possibility of additive, ynergistic, or antagonistic effects (Kadar et al., 2010).
Mussels are among the most studied invertebrates in marine nvironmental research, given their economic importance, sessile ehavior, size, and adaptation to environmental disturbances. Thus, hey represent a unique target group in the context of nanoparicle toxicity (Canesi et al., 2012). Marine bivalves lack adaptive mmunity and depend on the innate immune response to comat pathogens and parasites. Hemocytes of marine bivalves possess arious physiological functions, such as immune defense, detoxication, and tissue and shell repair (Ludovic et al., 2009). Cellular efense, which includes hemocytosis, phagocytosis, encapsulation, nd nacrezation, eliminates the invading foreign particles through he use of enzymes and reactive oxygen species in the hemoytes (Wang et al., 2011, 2012a). As filter feeders, mussels are ften used as a bioindicators for marine pollution (Cajaraville et al., 000), especially for testing nanoparticle toxicity, because musel hemocytes possess well developed endocytosis and phagocytic echanisms (Cajaraville and Pal, 1995; Canesi et al., 2012).
Previous studies have investigated the biological effects of either cean acidification or nano-TiO2 exposure on mussels (Canesi et al., 010; Fitzer et al., 2014; Wang et al., 2014). However, to our nowledge, the interactive effects of seawater acidification and anoparticles, such as nano-TiO2, in mussels and the underlying echanism remain obscure. To date, no information is available on he immunotoxicity of functionalized TiO2 nanoparticles in marine rganisms under ocean acidification stress. According to previus studies, the hemocyte is a key parameter in the activation f the immune system in mussels and thus one of the important argets for nanoparticle toxicity (Couleau et al., 2012). Flow cytomtry has been used in bivalve immunology because it provides
ology 180 (2016) 1–10
fast, accurate, and quantitative analyses of cell characteristics and immune-related functions (Park et al., 2012; Wang et al., 2012a). Therefore, we characterized the immune-related parameters of hemocytes for the first time, in vivo, in the mussel M. coruscus exposed to nano-TiO2 under seawater acidification conditions for 14 d followed by a 7 d recovery period. This survey was conducted to investigate and analyze the cellular immune functions of hemocytes: total hemocyte count, hemocyte mortality, phagocytosis, esterase activity, ROS production, and lysosomal content.
2. Materials and methods
2.1. Preparation and characterization of nano-TiO2
Nanosized titanium dioxide P25 (declared purity of 99.5%) from Sigma Aldrich was selected for the NP exposure. Stock suspensions (10 g nano-TiO2 L−1) were prepared in filtered artificial seawater, sonicated (UP200S, Hielscher Ultrasonic Technology, Teltow, Germany) for 15 min at 100 W in an ice bath. The following nominal concentrations of nano-TiO2 were selected for the experiment: 0, 2.5, and 10 mg L−1. X-ray diffraction analysis (XRD) patterns of nano-TiO2 were determined by X’Pert PRO X-ray Diffractometer (PANalytical B.V.). Primary particle size and morphology of nanoTiO2 were analyzed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Hitachi JSM-7500F) and transmission electron microscope (TEM, Low Voltage Tem5, LVEM5) equipped with a CCD camera. The particle size distribution was evaluated using the dynamic light scattering technique (DLS, Microtrac S3500, UK) both in seawater acidification (pH 7.3) and normal pH (pH 8.1) conditions.
2.2. Animals and treatments
Adult mussels (shell length: 6.98 ± 0.66 cm; wet weight 66.62 ± 2.76 g) were collected from the Shengsi island of Zhejiang Province, China, and acclimated to laboratory conditions for one week (temperature: 20 ± 0.5 ◦C; salinity 25 ± 1 psu). The mussels were cultured in aerated fiberglass aquarium (500 L) equipped with filtering systems and fed daily with the microalgae Chrysophyta spp. (5.0 × 105 cells mL−1) during the acclimation period. To study the combined effects of low pH and nano-TiO2, a factorial design was set up: two values of pH (7.3 as acidification and 8.1 as normal pH) and three concentrations of nano-TiO2 (0 [control], 2.5, and 10.0 mg L−1). The mussels were assigned to six treatments (2 pH × 3 TiO2) randomly. The low pH 7.3 of seawater was automatically manipulated by bubbling pure CO2 gas to maintain a constant low pH level estimated for the year 2300 (Caldeira and Wickett, 2003, 2005). The experiment lasted for 21 days (14 days of exposure and 7 days of recovery) in triplicates with 30 mussels per replicate (30 L aquarium) in each treatment. The low pH was achieved by aeration of pure CO2 using a pCO2/pH system (DAQ-M) equipped with WTW pH 3310 m and SenTix 41 pH electrodes (Loligo Systems Inc.). Seawater salinity was measured by a multiparameter instrument (model 5200A, YSI, USA). Total alkalinity (AT) was determined by titration method. Other parameters of the seawater carbonate chemistry, i.e., pCO2, dissolved inorganic carbon (DIC), saturation states of calcite ( ca), and aragonite ( ar), were calculated from AT and pHNBS using CO2sys (Lewis et al., 2013). Exposure tanks were dosed with certain volumes of the 10.0 g L−1 sonicated stock solution separately to achieve nano-TiO2 concentrations of 2.5 and 10 mg L−1. The water was changed every day, and new aliquots of nano-TiO2 solutions were added to maintain the nano-TiO2 at relatively constant levels for 14 d, followed by a recovery period of 7 d under pH 8.1 without nano-TiO2. During the experimental and recovery periods, the mussels were fed as in the acclimation period.

.3. Hemolymph collection and hemocyte counting
Hemolymph was withdrawn from the sinus of the posterior dductor muscle using a sterile syringe (1.0 mL) fitted with a 22G eedle after opening the shell with pincers. Unless otherwise indiated, at least 1.0 mL of collected hemolymph was immediately ransferred into a tube in ice to minimize spontaneous aggregaion of hemocytes (Chen et al., 2007). In all cases, the hemolymph as collected and pooled from three individual mussels in each eplicate tank. A particle size analyzer (MultisizerTM 3, Beckman oulter) was used to measure the concentration of hemocyte Wang et al., 2014).
.4. Flow cytometry
A BD AccuriTM C6 flow cytometer (BD Biosciences) was used o analyze the hemocyte parameters, including hemocyte mortalty, phagocytosis, esterase activity, lysosomal content, and reactive xygen species (ROS) content. A forward scatter (FSC) threshold as defined to exclude cell debris and bacteria. Data were recorded s cell cytograms showing the granularity (SSC value), relative size FSC value), and fluorescent channels for each parameter. Each samle analysis included a total of 20,000 events, and the flow speed as maintained at less than 300 s−1. Two fluorescent channels were et: hemocyte mortality was measured using FL2; and other hemoyte parameters were evaluated by FL1 (Wang et al., 2012b).
.5. Parameter measurements
Hemocyte mortality (HM) was measured using propidium odide (PI, 1.0 mg mL−1, Sigma Aldrich) (Delaporte et al., 2003). An liquot of 400 L hemolymph was incubated with 10 L of PI for 0 min in the dark at 4 ◦C. The percentage of HM was expressed s the ratio of cells showing PI fluorescence to the total number of ells.
Phagocytosis (Pha) was evaluated by an in vitro assay sing FluoSpheres® carboxylate-modified microspheres (diameer 1.0 m, yellow–green fluorescent, Invitrogen) (Gagnaire et al., 006a). An aliquot of the 400 L hemolymph was incubated with 0 L of the 1/10 dilution of fluorescent microspheres at ambient emperature for 1 h in the dark. Pha was defined as the proportion f hemocytes that had ingested at least three fluorescent beads.
Fluorescein diacetate (FDA, Sigma) was used to evaluate the on-specific esterase (Est) activity, which was defined on the basis f fluorescent cells among all cells (Gagnaire et al., 2008). An aliquot f the 400 L hemolymph was incubated with 2 L of the 1/10 diluion of FDA (400 M) at ambient temperature for 15 min in the ark.
ROS content was measured using 2′,7′-dichlorofluorescein diactate (DCFH-DA; Sigma) and defined on the basis of fluorescent cells mong all cells in arbitrary units (Delaporte et al., 2003). An aliquot f the 400 L hemolymph and 4 L of DCFH-DA were mixed and ncubated for 15 min at ambient temperature in the dark. Lysosomal content (defined as mean intensity of LysoTracker
uorescence exhibited by all the hemocytes in arbitrary units)
as determined using LysoTracker® Yellow HCK-123 (1 mM in MSO, Invitrogen). One L of a LysoTracker was added to 400 L emolymph, and hemolymph samples were incubated for 2 h in he dark at room temperature (Gagnaire et al., 2008).

2.6. Statistical analyses
Before analysis, data were tested for normality by ShapiroWilk’s test and homogeneity of variance by Levene’s test using SPSS 18.0. Arcsine transformation of percentage data was carried out. The effects of nano-TiO2, pH and their interactions were analyzed by two-way analysis of variance (ANOVA). If an interaction existed, the significant effects of nano-TiO2 were analyzed by oneway ANOVA at each fixed pH value followed by Tukey’s HSD test to determine which treatments were different. Significant effects of pH were analyzed for each nano-TiO2 concentration using Student’s t-test. Principal component analysis (PCA) was carried out using XLSTAT®2014. A biplot was graphed with both the measured parameters and the observations. For all analysis, significant differences were considered at P < 0.05.
3. Results
3.1. Water chemistry
Carbonate chemistry parameters of seawater within each treatment are summarized in Table 1. Salinity values were maintained at 25 ± 0.4 psu, and water temperature during the experiment was maintained at 20 ± 0.3 ◦C. All mussels were alive during the experimental period.
3.2. Nano-TiO2 characterization
XRD demonstrated that the main crystalline phases of nanoTiO2 P25 were anatase and rutile with peaks at 25.3◦ and 27.4◦, respectively, in accordance with the product report (Fig. 1A). The size distribution of nano-TiO2 in filtered seawater determined by DLS is presented in Fig. 1B. The average particle size of nano-TiO2 was 975 nm in pH 7.3, whereas that in pH 8.1 was 1054 nm. The morphology of nano-TiO2 was examined by both SEM and TEM. The typical spheroid irregular shape of nano-TiO2 and particle diameter of approximately 20–30 nm were confirmed by SEM and TEM, respectively (Fig. 1C and D).
3.3. Total hemocyte count
Total hemocyte count (THC) significantly decreased with pH reduction and nano-TiO2 concentration increase (Fig. 2), and the interactions between pH and nano-TiO2 were observed at 7 and 14 d (Table 2). At 7 d, the THC was significantly reduced by nanoTiO2 under normal pH conditions, and THC of 10 mg L−1 nano-TiO2 group was significantly lower than that of 0 mg L−1 nano-TiO2 group under low pH 7.3. At 14 d, when pH was 8.1, significantly low THC values were observed in 2.5 and 10 mg L−1 nano-TiO2 treatments compared with the 0 mg L−1 nano-TiO2 treatment. By contrast, when pH was 7.3, an insignificant difference was observed between the three treatments. THC was significantly lower at low pH when the concentrations of nano-TiO2 were 0 and 2.5 mg L−1 at 14 d. During the recovery period, the effects of nano-TiO2 on THC were also significant, and pH also showed significant effects at certain nano-TiO2 treatments (Fig. 2). In general, THC values after recovery increased compared with that during the exposure period.
3.4. Hemocyte mortality
Hemocyte mortality (HM) was significantly affected by both pH and nano-TiO2, and a significant interaction between these two factors was observed at 3, 7, and 14 d (Table 2). In general, HM was higher when the mussels were exposed in high nano-TiO2 and low pH conditions, and it increased with time (Fig. 3). The variation trends of HM caused by nano-TiO2 had a remarkable resemblance

3.5. Phagocytosis
Phagocytosis (Pha) was significantly affected by low pH and nano-TiO2 throughout the experiment (Table 2). During the whole exposure period, the interactive effect between pH and nano-TiO2

Low pH and high nano-TiO2 showed significant effects on the sterase (Est) activity throughout the experiment, and significant nteractions between pH and nano-TiO2 were found during the xposure period (Table 2). At all exposure time points, exposure o 10 mg L−1 nano-TiO2 led to a significant decrease of Est activty compared with 0 mg L−1 nano-TiO2 (Fig. 5). At 7 and 14 d, Est ctivity at low pH showed no difference compared with normal pH hen nano-TiO2 was 10 mg L−1. No recovery was observed during he recovery period (Fig. 5).
.7. Reactive oxygen species
Reactive oxygen species (ROS) content was significantly altered y pH and nano-TiO2 throughout the experiment, and pH and nanoiO2 exhibited significant interactions at 7 and 14 d (Table 2).
Generally, ROS content was higher when the mussels were exposed to low pH or high concentrations of nano-TiO2 (Fig. 6). At 14 d, ROS content significantly increased with nano-TiO2 increment under both low pH and normal pH conditions. During the recovery period, ROS was significantly higher in 10 mg L−1 nano-TiO2 than 0 mg L−1 nano-TiO2 under each pH treatment, whereas there was no pH effect in the 0 mg L−1 nano-TiO2 (Fig. 6).
3.8. Lysosomal content
Lysosomal content (Lyso) was significantly reduced by low pH and high nano-TiO2, but no interactive effect was evident during the exposure period (Fig. 7, Table 2). At 21 d, previous nano-TiO2 exposure continuously induced a significant reduction on Lyso, with the lowest values observed in the 10 mg L−1 nano-TiO2 treatment for both pH levels, and the interaction between pH and nano-TiO2 was also evident (Fig. 7, Table 2).
3.9. Principal component analysis
Principal component analysis (PCA) showed that 90.20% and 93.40% of overall variance were explained by the two principal components during the exposure and recovery period, respectively. During the exposure period, PC1 expressed 81.65% of overall variance, showing the most significant result referred to the separation between high nano-TiO2 and 0 nano-TiO2 treatments (Fig. 8A). During the recovery period, PC1 representing 85.36% of total variance showed a similar trend to the exposure period (Fig. 8B).
4. Discussion
Nano-TiO2 has been applied in numerous commercial products, which may ultimately enter aquatic environments. Hence, an urgent evaluation of the toxic effects of nano-TiO2 on aquatic organisms is necessary to understand the mechanisms of its toxicity. Marine bivalves, which are primarily sediment dwellers and filter feeders, accumulate NPs by cell endocytosis and phagocytosis (Canesi et al., 2012). Thus, their tissues, such as gills, digestive glands, and circulating hemocytes, are at high risk of injury. According to previous studies, polystyrene microsphere agglomerates were translocated in the hemocytes of M. edulis, which elicited bioaccumulation and toxic effects (Browne et al., 2008). Given the various factors, such as NP size, pH, salinity, ionic strength, metal

omposition, and natural organic matter (Canesi et al., 2008; Ward nd Kach, 2009), the trend to form NP aggregates can be exacerated in the marine environment. Ward and Kach (2009) indicated hat mussels and oysters more efficiently capture and ingest NPs hat are incorporated into aggregates compared with those freely uspended. In the present study, the low pH in seawater altered he physiochemical properties of NPs and led to a slightly greater ggregation of nano-TiO2. Hence, under acidification, the mussels ccumulated more TiO2 NPs than in the normal pH condition, which ay accordingly cause more severe toxic effects. In our experient, particle sedimentation and larger agglomerate trapped in ucus were visually observed after some hours, which may impair he respiration of mussels. For the physiological effect of acidificaion, the mussel M. galloprovincialis exhibited a metabolic response fter exposure to acidified water as the rate of oxygen consumpion decreased significantly (Michaelidis et al., 2005). Thus, both cidification and NP may exert negative effects on the physiology nd immunology of mussels. The combined effects of nano-TiO2
and pH are complicated, and our results showed some synergistic interactive effects on immune response in mussels.
In bivalves, the immune system is mainly dependent on the circulating hemocytes that perform immune surveillance. THC decreased in the clam Villorita cyprinoide following exposure to copper, implying that the immunity of bivalves could be negatively affected by metals (Suresh and Mohandas, 1990). A similar phenomenon occurred in other pollutants as well. Fisher et al. (2000) found a reduced concentration of hemocytes in the oyster Crassostrea virginica under long-term stress of petroleum hydrocarbon. Meseck et al. (2016) indicated that ocean acidification also resulted in decreased THC of the crab Chionoecetes bairdi. Similarly, in the present study, THC decreased with nano-TiO2 concentration increase and pH decrease. This finding is possibly supported by the effects of pollution exposure on mussel, where a decrease in THC corresponds with cytolysis in lysosome-rich cells, such as hemocytes (McCormick-Ray, 1987). The result of low THC of mussels exposed to acidification and nano-TiO2 indicates a depressed immunological response, and it is unlikely for mussels to be capable of responding efficiently against pathogens and/or chemical substances (Akaishi et al., 2007).
Hemocyte mortality evaluated by propidium iodide is dependent on membrane integrity; thus, the distinction between necrotic or apoptotic cells is vague (Hégaret et al., 2003). Wang et al. (2013) suggested that lysosomal damage caused by NP exposure can increase the amount of apoptotic cell death. Caza et al. (2015) observed the induction of cell death in mussel hemocytes from both M. edulis and Aulacomya ater exposed to cadmium. In M. coruscus hemocytes, the significantly increased HM was found as a result of a nano-TiO2 exposure, indicating a high susceptibility to NP, which agrees with the result on the green-lipped mussel Perna viridis (Wang et al., 2014). Moreover, similar results were also obtained for the oyster C. gigas under acidification (Wang et al., 2016), suggesting that a significant increase of HM may be associated with insufficient antioxidant enzyme activities induced by stress. Additionally, significant interaction was found at 7 and 14 d, implying that pH and nano-TiO2 brought a more severe effect to mussel in the long-term exposure.
Phagocytosis is an integral part of cellular defense and a key
Environmental stressors and pollutants are postulated to reduce immunocompetence by altering the phagocytic activity of hemocytes; thus, phagocytosis would provide a solid index of the

otentially adverse effects of such factors on mussels (Coles et al., 995; Luengen et al., 2004). Interestingly, a rapid lysosomal destailization was observed for the mussel M. galloprovincialis exposed o polystyrene NPs, which was accompanied with decreased phagoytosis (Canesi et al., 2015). Our data showed that exposure to ano-TiO2 induced a dramatic decrease in phagocytosis and lysoomal content, indicating an impairment of immunocompetence in . coruscus. Such a decrease in phagocytosis has also been reported n the green-lipped mussel P. viridis as a result of NP exposure Wang et al., 2014). Additionally, Canesi et al. (2015) reported that hagocytosis of the mussel M. galloprovincialis exposed to high oncentration of polystyrene nanoparticles decreased, and simiar responses were also observed under acidification (Bibby et al., 008). Wang et al. (2016) found a reduction of phagocytosis induced y low pH. Although limited information is available on mechaisms for phagocytosis reduction caused by NP and acidification, ysosomal destabilization seems to be one of the possible causes. urthermore, in the present study, interactions between pH and ano-TiO2 occurred from 1 d to 7 d, indicating that phagocytic ctivity could be inhibited by the synergistic effects of low pH and ano-TiO2 if mussels were exposed for a longer period.
Esterase is usually considered as a type of hydrolase enzyme in emocytes involved in the intracellular degradation (Mottin et al., 010). Esterase activity could be inhibited by contaminants and ome environmental disturbances in mussels and regarded as a ensitive biomarker for monitoring polluted environments (Wang t al., 2011; Xian et al., 2014). A previous study on the oyster rassostrea gigas showed a significant decrease of esterase activity ith suppression of the immune system under exposure to some esticides and polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (Gagnaire et al., 006b). In the present study, similar results were present in M. oruscus exposed to pH and nano-TiO2. This result was probably aused by the elevated ROS content; hence, the degrading activity of sterase is considered a consequence of oxidative stress (Paital and hainy, 2010; Xian et al., 2014). Xian et al. (2013) pointed out that he declining cell viability could preliminarily explain the lowered sterase activity of hemocytes. Based on our results, esterase could lso be a sensitive biomarker of ocean acidification and nano-TiO2.
Respiratory burst plays a key role in the innate immune esponse, resulting in production of oxygen metabolites (Pipe, 992). The capability to produce ROS is a solid index that can be sed to evaluate the toxic effect of NPs (Xia et al., 2006). ROS of M. dulis exposed to nano-TiO2 showed a concentration-dependent ffect with an increase with increased NP concentration (Canesi t al., 2010). In our experiment, ROS production evaluated by flow ytometry showed an increase under nano-TiO2 conditions, sugesting that exposure to nano-TiO2 stimulates the ability of mollusk emocytes to produce ROS. We speculated that high ROS prouction may be a way to compensate for the lower number of emocytes in our study. Akaishi et al. (2007) pointed out that high OS content under stress conditions is a mechanism to implement ompensating actions for the lower phagocytic activity. The pH ffect on ROS was also the same. In the oyster C. gigas, a signifiant increase of ROS was observed after one month of exposure to cidification (Wang et al., 2016). Based on our results, the signifiant interaction started from 14 d. Even in the recovery period, low H could accentuate the negative effect induced by nano-TiO2.
Lysosome is an essential bacteriolytic cellular organelle that rovides the main pathway for intracellular degradation as well s host defense against pathogenic bacteria by releasing differnt hydrolytic enzymes (Olsen et al., 2003). In bivalves, lysosome s widely known to be a considerable indicator of the vitality of he defense system (Moore, 2002). Few studies are available about he relationship between pH and lysosomal content, but the cytooxic effect of nano-TiO2 on M. galloprovincialis was observed in itro, inducing a concentration-dependent decrease of lysozyme
ology 180 (2016) 1–10
release (Canesi et al., 2008, 2015). Similar results were found in this study for the mussels exposed to similar nano-TiO2 concentrations (0–10 mg L−1). TiO2 NPs caused inflammatory responses, oxidative stress, and histopathological alterations in different animal species and to some degree contributed to the functional disturbance of lysosome (Federici et al., 2007; Jemec et al., 2008; Canesi et al., 2012; Barmo et al., 2013). In the present study, lysosomal content was significantly reduced by low pH and high nano-TiO2 during the exposure period, suggesting that immunity of mussels was impaired by NPs under acidification.
Among the immune responses in M. coruscus, the recovery from low pH and/or nano-TiO2 was not evident, although THC, HM, Pha, and Lyso generally showed a slight recovery along with time. Regarding the THC recovery of M. edulis from cadmium exposure, the mussels showed a reversible response, implying the stimulation of cell production under normal conditions (Coles et al., 1995). The phagocytosis recovery rate of abalone Haliotis diversicolor from tributyltin and benzo[a]pyrene exposure was low (Gopalakrishnan et al., 2011), which was in accordance with our result. This finding may be due to the hemocyte membrane instability and persistent effect of the chemicals. M. coruscus exposed to low pH and high concentrations of nano-TiO2 showed continuously increased levels of HM and ROS compared with the control treatment. Some immune parameters could be inhibited further if mussels were exposed for a longer period to the low pH and high NP concentrations, even if these stressors were removed. Although the mechanisms leading to the impairment of hemocyte parameters were not clear, pH and nano-TiO2 brought a severe adverse effect to mussels with some carry-over effects even when the mussels were returned to normal conditions.
For integration of immune parameter changes, PCA was used to differentiate combined effects as a function of principal components. During the exposure period, PC1 strongly reflected changes of all immune parameters, distinguishing high-concentration nano-TiO2 treatments from the control, because most normal treatments (0 mg nano-TiO2) were brought together by PC1 showing similar immune responses. Comparison of ANOVA with PCA showed that the characteristics of hemocyte function associated with the nano-TiO2 stress were lower Pha, Lyso, Est, and THC coupled with higher ROS and HM. A similar phenomenon during the recovery period was observed, indicating the carry-over effects of nano-TiO2. However, the hemocyte responses of low pH exposed mussels were not very clear based on PCA.
In conclusion, nano-TiO2 and low pH affected hemocyte responses of the mussel M. coruscus with interactive and carry-over effects. Furthermore, the influence of high-concentration nanoTiO2 was greater than that of acidification. Results from this work do not reflect realistic environmental exposure conditions, but the study represents the first effort to estimate the responses of marine mussels exposed to combined acidification and nanomaterials. Moreover, nano-TiO2 may affect mussel health more severely when seawater acidification is present.

metadata.abstractText: With increasing production from nanotechnology industries, nanomaterials are inevitably released into the aquatic environment, thereby posing a potential risk to aquatic organisms. Thus, concerns have been raised on the potential ecotoxicological effect of nanoparticle. Furthermore, the ecotoxicological consequences caused by the interaction of nanoparticles with other environmental stresses, such as seawater acidification on marine animals, have not been evaluated. In particular, whether acidification enhances the susceptibility to nanoparticles in bivalves needs to be evaluated. In the present study, we investigated the combined effects of low pH and nanoscale titanium dioxide (nano-TiO2) on some immune parameters of hemocytes in the mussel Mytilus coruscus by flow cytometry under six combinations of two pH values (7.3 and 8.1) and three nano-TiO2 concentrations (0, 2.5, and 10 mg L−1) for 14 d. Afterward, the mussels were shifted to normal conditions without nano-TiO2 at pH 8.1 for 7 d further to test their recovery from the multiple stresses. Total hemocyte count (THC), phagocytosis (Pha), esterase (Est), and lysosomal content (Lyso) decreased under low pH and high nano-TiO2 concentration conditions, whereas hemocyte mortality (HM) and reactive oxygen species (ROS) increased with nano-TiO2 concentrations under low pH conditions. The interactive effects between pH and nano-TiO2 were observed at the latter part of the exposure experiment (7 and 14 d) in most hemocyte parameters. Nano-TiO2 influenced the immune functions of mussel more severely than low pH. Slight recovery from the combined stresses was observed for HM, THC, Pha, and Lyso, but significant carry-over effects of nano-TiO2 and low pH were still observed. This study demonstrated that both low pH and high concentration of nano-TiO2 had negative effects on mussels, and these effects still acted for some time even though the mussels were already out of such stressors. © 2016 Elsevier B.V.
